awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Small: Investigating Stealthy Hardware Trojans
awd_abstract_narration:
Many systems ranging from consumer electronics to military equipment are dependent on integrated circuits (ICs). Thus, if the underlying IC in a system is maliciously manipulated by a hardware trojan, then the security of the entire system can be compromised. This project investigates hardware Trojans that do not rely on additional logic to affect security.

The researchers study a class of Trojans that can be realized using low-level manipulations like subtle changes in logic, circuit or manufacturing process. They investigate scenarios where an attacker may take advantage of such manipulations, and develops countermeasures to protect ICs against hardware Trojans. This project explores new threat assessments for many applications of practical relevance. Considering society's reliance on integrated circuits, understanding the threat posed by low-level Trojans in IC design and manufacturing supply chain is of great importance.

por.por_cntn:
Integrated circuits underpin critical functions of our society in the area of energy infrastructure, medical devices, and defense systems, among others. The design and fabrication of integrated circuits involves a large number of actors, and there is a realistic threat that one or more of these actors could make malicious modifications to the circuits. These malicious modifications are referred to as Hardware Trojans. Hardware Trojans that are unknowingly inserted into integrated circuits could weaken the security of the critical systems that rely on the circuits as components.

The hardware security research community studies techniques that might prevent or detect Hardware Trojans, but does so with limited understanding of what form the Trojans might take. The gap in our collective understanding of Hardware Trojans hinders our ability to defend against the threat of Trojans. This research project aims to improve our understanding of Trojans by studying the design of stealthy Trojans that require only miniscule alterations of the integrated circuits, and therefore would be especially difficult to detect. The project has focused on three thrusts: (1) circuit-level technologies that can enact hard-to-detect changes, (2) cryptographic exploits that leverage the small circuit-level changes to create protocol-level weaknesses, and (3) improved methods for Trojan detection that are informed by our findings from the first two thrusts.

The project has funded four PhD students at UMass Amherst, has lead to over a dozen publications in competitive and highly-competitive venues, and raised awareness from the community about the threats of Hardware Trojans and how to guard against these threats. Notably, our research has shown that it is possible to create significant cryptographic weaknesses by transistor-level changes that would be nearly-impossible to detect during normal usage over the lifetime of the circuit. A key publication of this project introduced for the first time a comprehensive classification of hardware obfuscation, and is already widely cited in the scientific community. Our research has also demonstrated that seemingly-innocuous components such as power-management units can pose significant threats if infected by Trojans. The awareness raised by this project, and knowledge created through this research, helps to safeguard critical systems against potentially crippling hardware Trojans.
